pullrequest.title: Fix QT rendering, and rendering update rate (DEFAULT)

content.raw: @scpeters, @ichen and I looked at this branch with the double pendulum example and noticed that the FPS drops to around 8-15 when moving the mouse. On default, the FPS is around 30 with no mouse events, and on this branch, the FPS is around 50-60. I confirmed with branch `default_fps` that the low FPS is reproducible on default. @ichen is looking into the mouse events, I think.
content.html: @scpeters, @ichen and I looked at this branch with the double pendulum example and noticed that the FPS drops to around 8-15 when moving the mouse. On default, the FPS is around 30 with no mouse events, and on this branch, the FPS is around 50-60. I confirmed with branch default_fps that the low FPS is reproducible on default. @ichen is looking into the mouse events, I think.

content.raw: The mouse movement affect is caused by the selection buffer. Tuning of the selection buffer can be done in a separate pull request.
content.html: The mouse movement affect is caused by the selection buffer. Tuning of the selection buffer can be done in a separate pull request.

content.raw: On OS X, this is around 26-28 FPS, but it looks much smoother than Ubuntu (no intermittent choppiness).
content.html: On OS X, this is around 26-28 FPS, but it looks much smoother than Ubuntu (no intermittent choppiness).

pullrequest.title: Fix QT rendering, and rendering update rate (DEFAULT)

content.raw:
I just built the `default_fps` branch for comparison, and the FPS with no mouse movement is 28-29 in both branches. With mouse movement, this branch drops to 24-25, while `default_fps` drops to 14-15. So this is a definite improvement.

It's strange, though, that the performance is so different between OS X and Ubuntu. I'll show people tomorrow on my laptop.
content.html:
I just built the default_fps branch for comparison, and the FPS with no mouse movement is 28-29 in both branches. With mouse movement, this branch drops to 24-25, while default_fps drops to 14-15. So this is a definite improvement.

It's strange, though, that the performance is so different between OS X and Ubuntu. I'll show people tomorrow on my laptop.

pullrequest.title: Fix QT rendering, and rendering update rate (DEFAULT)

content.raw: On this branch, I still get test failures in the Qtests that are really bothering me, and they both segfault after failing, in `MainWindow::CopyPaste` and `TimePanel::Visibility`.
content.html: On this branch, I still get test failures in the Qtests that are really bothering me, and they both segfault after failing, in MainWindow::CopyPaste and TimePanel::Visibility.

pullrequest.title: Fix QT rendering, and rendering update rate (DEFAULT)

content.raw:
Awesome discoveries about these failing tests.

I get segfaults in both after the first test case passes and while the second test case passes.

When I move the declaration of the first test further down in the header file, all tests pass and no segfault happens.

When I copy the new test in `MainWindow_TEST` from this branch to default and comment out the QVERIFY statements for average FPS, or change the FPS to something more reasonable, I see the same behavior: crash and failure if the UserCameraFPS case is declared first, pass if it is declared last.

To me this is indicative of faulty behavior in QTestFixture. It may also be indicative of a bug in the gui library, but I would expect the different test cases to have isolated states.

Since I've verified this problem on default, I'm fine with approving this pull request, with the caveat that it might have behavior that causes lots of qtest failures. Can anyone else confirm the crashing and reordering on their machine?
content.html:
Awesome discoveries about these failing tests.

I get segfaults in both after the first test case passes and while the second test case passes.

When I move the declaration of the first test further down in the header file, all tests pass and no segfault happens.

When I copy the new test in MainWindow_TEST from this branch to default and comment out the QVERIFY statements for average FPS, or change the FPS to something more reasonable, I see the same behavior: crash and failure if the UserCameraFPS case is declared first, pass if it is declared last.

To me this is indicative of faulty behavior in QTestFixture. It may also be indicative of a bug in the gui library, but I would expect the different test cases to have isolated states.

Since I've verified this problem on default, I'm fine with approving this pull request, with the caveat that it might have behavior that causes lots of qtest failures. Can anyone else confirm the crashing and reordering on their machine?

pullrequest.title: Fix QT rendering, and rendering update rate (DEFAULT)

content.raw:
I've seen this problem before. This is most likely due to gazebo not cleaning up properly between the test cases. From experience, this could be:

-  scene, visual shared pointers are still kept alive 

-  the state of singleton classes are not reset. 

- previous gazebo events connections are still alive
content.html:
I've seen this problem before. This is most likely due to gazebo not cleaning up properly between the test cases. From experience, this could be:

  • scene, visual shared pointers are still kept alive

  • the state of singleton classes are not reset.

  • previous gazebo events connections are still alive

Ian has a lot of good ideas about what could be wrong (and these might be indicative of bugs in the gui library).
content.html: like GlWidget test 1 and 2? It's a viable workaround, but I think we should eventually get to the bottom of the issue. Ian has a lot of good ideas about what could be wrong (and these might be indicative of bugs in the gui library).
